title: 105_hr4240
content:
The Act is titled the "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" and addresses liability for computer date failure. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" addresses liability for computer date failure in cases where only contract-based recovery for consequential business loss and repair costs is allowed if certain conditions are met, excluding personal injury claims. The defendant must provide notice to buyers about potential computer date failures. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires defendants to provide notice to buyers about potential computer date failures and offer free repair or replacement for affected computer programs or hardware introduced after December 31, 1994. For products introduced before January 1, 1995, repair or replacement must also be provided. The notice must specify the affected system or component and explain how buyers can obtain repairs. The buyer can obtain repair or replacement of the computer system, component, program, or software. Contracting parties can still agree on liability and damages for computer date failure. A person engaged in commerce is defined as a person designing, developing, or manufacturing computer systems. Actions against a person for computer date failure are based solely on contract, allowing recovery for business loss and repair costs. The plaintiff can recover consequential business loss and repair costs resulting from a computer date failure if certain conditions are met. The defendant must have made efforts to prevent the failure and tested systems for Y2K compliance. The defendant must provide notice to customers and the President's Council on the Year 2000 Conversion by August 1, 1999, detailing efforts to avoid computer date failure and the likelihood of transitioning to the Year 2000 without issues. The notice must also be posted prominently in their place of business for public review. The President's Council will make the notice available on its website. This subsection does not limit contracting parties' ability to enter into agreements. The section limits contracting parties' ability to enter into agreements on liability and damages related to computer date failure. Definitions include "action" for legal claims and "computer date failure" for system inaccuracies between 1999 and beyond. The term "computer program or software" refers to a set of instructions used in a computer to achieve a specific result. A "computer system" includes electronic devices, networks, and embedded chips that perform functions like logic, arithmetic, data processing, and communication. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY ANTITRUST EXEMPTION.

Antitrust laws do not apply to conduct aimed at addressing computer date failure until December 31, 2001, except for actions resulting in a boycott. The definition of antitrust laws includes federal and state regulations related to unfair competition.
